awd_titl_txt: A New Technician Training Program for Advanced Building Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to prepare future Air Conditioning, Heating, and Refrigeration (AHR) technicians for the rapidly changing technological advances in Building Automation Technology.  Knowledge and skills in Building Automation Technology are not included in traditional AHR training. This project intends to address a serious workforce shortage in AHR by training skilled technicians to install and maintain advanced building technologies. The project team will work with industry to develop educational materials, equip a new laboratory, recruit students into the Building Automation Technology pathway, and share best practices. Qualified Building Automation Technology technicians will serve the national interest by ensuring that buildings reach their potential energy efficiency, contributing to energy savings that have positive environmental impacts and national security implications. Properly implemented building controls, which students will learn in apprenticeships and in a new Building Automation Technology laboratory, will also improve occupants’ productivity and health.

This project will create a new Building Automation Technology program to prepare students for new and high-demand technical careers. Goals include developing four new Building Automation Technology courses and a building technology laboratory to support the courses; providing faculty professional development opportunities; and recruiting new students into the program, especially women and underrepresented minorities. The project will work with the Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow Center and industry partners to ensure that the program will be aligned with industry workforce needs and will result in high quality educational resources, including a Building Automation Technology laboratory that emulates actual building conditions. The Building Automation Technology program will support life-long educational pathways including work-based learning, apprenticeships, and four-year options. Upon validation of the curriculum and laboratory best practices, materials will be disseminated across the North Carolina Community College System and through the Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow Center. This project will help inform the technical education community about effective practices for recruiting women and underrepresented minorities, implementing apprenticeship programs, and developing Building Automation Technology programs. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

  • Award Title:  NSF ATE A New Technician Training Program for Advanced Building Technologies (FACT)
  • Federal Award ID: 2000190
  • Report Submission Period: July 1, 2020, through December 31, 2024

A new technician training program for Advanced Building Technologies was funded under an NSF ATE project for $455,641.  The program aimed to address workforce shortages in Air Conditioning, Heating, and Refrigeration (AHR) by training skilled technicians to install and maintain advanced building automation systems. At that time in 2020, there was no comparable training available in North Carolina. The project was awarded in July 2020 and closed in December 2024, which included an extension of a year and a half needed due to COVID-19 pandemic delays and AHR instructor turnover.  Through the support of this project, a new Building Automation Technologies (BAT) lab was fully equipped, and four new courses that form the basis of the BAT program were developed. 

The BAT lab supports 16 independent student workstations with individual controllers, sensors, actuators, and Variable Air Volume (VAV) boxes.  The 16 VAV boxes are also connected by an air handling unit (AHU), a chiller, and a boiler, which students can control.  An additional AHU and chiller allows students to test and experiment with different configurations.

Four new courses were successfully built as part of our program development goals, and the introductory course was redesigned:

  • Building Automation Systems” (BAT 111)
  • Building Automation Technology Logic and Programing” (BAT 212)
  • Building Automation Systems Networking” (BAT 221)
  • Building Automation Systems Integration” (BAT 231)
  • Building Automation Controls” (BAT 251)

These courses cover networking, programming, system integration, and process control as applied to building systems. Additionally, the BAT degree was added as a second-year option for the AHR degree. Industry workers who already have a degree in AHR can attend the second-year option and get a second degree in BAT. A Certificate with 12 to 18 credits required in strictly BAT training was also added for individuals with sufficient related experience.

Participation of instructors through attendance at conferences, workshops, and individual consultations with the NSF ATE Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow (BEST) Center provided the ability to better incorporate industry standards into training, software, and equipment planning during curriculum development. Wake Tech further strengthened its partnership with the BEST Center by participating in annual conferences and workshops. Wake Tech also solicited input from local companies by holding a facilitated day-long Job Task Analysis, with CMS Controls, Brady Trane, Siemens, Schneider Electric, ECS Engineered Control Solutions, and RDU Airport Authority in attendance.  Many of these businesses supported the college throughout the grant through class visits, providing curriculum materials, and reviewing learning goals as they were developed.

After the full development of class training and activities, an effort was made to disseminate our work to other community colleges through an Open Educational Resource (OER) website.  The goal of this sharing effort is to provide small, rural colleges with a more cost-effective way to plan for and offer their own Building Automation program. Curriculum materials, plans for the trainers, and the corresponding labs are available at https://www.waketech.edu/programs-courses/credit/building-automation/curriculum-materials.

The success of the project is measured, in part, but the successful enrollment in each of the newly developed and redesigned courses, impacting 393 students and a course completion rate of 89%. In addition, approximately 35 unique visits each quarter to the OER website for the materials developed through this project demonstrates the interest among North Carolina community colleges and beyond.
